Space-Time is obviously not flat, it's "cubic" since it is three-dimensional at any given time, and bends in localised areas around objects with mass. Over large distances the gravitational warping caused by mass doesn't really matter as it ceases to bend space-time outside its area of effect. As for the amount of mass in the universe, I don't believe in coincidences, not on the grand scale: perhaps our fundamentals are wrong, that mass can be created and destroyed, and perhaps the amount of mass created and destroyed is determined by universal constants so it comes out almost "even", or perhaps, due to my first point, the amount of mass density is pretty much irrelevant in the grand scale.

Hrm... the two explanations that come to mind are:
1) The Anthropic Principle: It really is a coincidence, but with the possibility for many or infinite universes, we just happened to evolve in the one that could support us. Or rather, if we were considering one of the (likely common) universes that didn't have this random coincidence, intelligent life wouldn't exist to ask why. We're looking at this coincidence and impressed because we could exist thanks to the coincidence, nothing more.
2) Feedback Loop: Perhaps it's not at all a coincidence that the universe is approximately flat, because some form of feedback between space and energy/matter affects the growth of space and the creation of matter. Space and its contents affect each other during and after the big bang, and flatness is an ideal shape that the universe tends towards for reasons we don't necessarily understand, but any given universe will tend to go that way.

I’ve always liked the idea of a flat universe. If you think about it, you know where live in three spatial dimensions. But how could the universe be flat when it is obviously three dimensions you ask? That is because the universe is flat, but in a higher dimension. What’s a flat object in the fourth spatial dimension? A Kline Bottle!
The universe may very well be shaped in a Kline Bottle. This means that if you were to go completely straight without bending or changing direction in any way for a very long time, you would end up back where you started, but upside down. You would never have changed position or direction, you would simply be upside down.

To those of you who don’t know, a Kline Bottle is a Mobius Loop but in a higher dimension. The loop is technically 3D, but exists in the second dimension making it a flat object. Bring it up a dimension and the shape becomes impossible, and we have to create something similar enough just to visualize it.

These experiments assume that the part of the universe can observe is substantial enough to make such an estimate on the entirety of the universe. That seems like a horrible assumption. Imagine you live on the inflection point of a parabola, and you can see out 0.0000000000000000000000000000000000001 units in either direction. To you, looks like you're on the tangent line of that curve. The same is true for a 3d surface, your triangle measurements will all look like you're talking about a flat plane. Guessing the curvature of space with what we know is pretty much useless speculation. For all we know we're seeing some infinitesimally small part of it, or we're seeing some large portion of it, and we can't currently know that.

SRT is theory without gravity-masses.
SRT describes physics in the absence of gravity-masses
That means - the ''absolute spacetime'' as whole is a flat continuum.
This means that in ''absolute spacetime'' ( without gravity-masses ) light / light quanta
must (!) travel only (!) on straight line (!) and not ''on geodesics '' / not on curved line.
But the movement of light is curved only (!) by local gravity-masses : GRT.

the answer is hourglass. the present is a point of infinitesimal dimension. each person or position in space has its own mutually exclusive present. the immediate causal past and future are confined to a small physical space that very quickly expands and merges spatially with the observable universes of others as time in either direction increases as a factor, so that the cosmic background radiation from billions of years ago that defines your total observable universe in LA or New York or Tokyo is indistinguishable from the one observed here in Denver.

the past is a light cone. the future is a light cone. that's not just a diagram of time. it's how space is shaped. there is no space parallel to us in time a million light years away. it is not there. that space is in the past and in the future, but from our vantage, not only can it not be seen, it does not exist in the present, as part of the observable universe that any of our math applies to, because space doesn't work that way. the space between two points includes in its definition the time it takes to connect them. in the absolute sense, there is no such thing as any parallel space in the present. even brain impulses require time to tell us about what we are experiencing "right here and now" because we operate mentally by condensing a region of things happening in generally the same space and time as happening at a point, that point being the self. a point is a useful mathematical convention, but only as long as we remember that we say right in the definition that it has no dimension. spatial dimension is itself an equation that includes the factor (x Time).

I feel like the idea of multiple coexistant universes solves the problem of why our universe has the right matter density to be flat. Firstly, we exist in exactly the way we do (with the ability to question the universe exactly the way we do) as a direct result of the conditions of our universe. And secondly, and this is more of a probabilistic approach, if there are a huge amount of possibilities for how a universe might start, there is a pretty decent chance that a universe with exactly this amount of curvature will exist, and a similarly good chance that beings will evolve in that universe to question it.

Of course, this doesn't account for the possibility that there might not be a nearly-unlimited amount of possible start conditions for a universe, but that's probably not something we'll be able to measure unless we find a way of directly observing other universes (and observing our own universe externally), which seems unlikely to ever occur.

Maybe you shouldn't have said that space is flat BECUASE the energy density is just right, which sounds misleading, but rather that it is measured to be flat due to the fact that that is compatible with the expansion measured since the emission of the cosmic microwave background. The cosmological principle leads to the Friedmann equations, in which the sign of the curvature is set as an initial condition and cannot change with the energy density (only its value changes, as space expands). And, as you said, space may not be perfectly flat, but just have a very small curvature. This was considered a problem until inflation became a part of the standard cosmological model, after which any reasonable initial curvature becomes negligible.

Based on this, I think the best visualization of space-time in 3 dimensions is a torus. Since space-time is 4-dimensional and consists of 3 space and 1 time dimension, it basically means that if the universe is spherical (which would be logical if it expanded from a single point), it has to be spherical in all 4 dimensions. We can't see bodies in 4 dimensions, but 4-dimensional bodies have projections in 3 dimensions, just like 3-dimensional bodies have projections in 2 dimensions and so on (For example, the 2d-projection of a sphere is a circle). 3d-projections of 4d-bodies are called Hyperbodies, the projection of a 4d-sphere is therefore called a "Hypersphere" and mathematically it so happens to look similar to a torus (some error included). This torus-shape would also explain why we can't determine the center of the universe or where it expands from, because that point would be the radial center of the torus, which is outside of the body itself.
Bear in mind, this is all my personal hypothesis. I can't remember where i first heard about hyperspheres, but I believe it connects very well to the theory of a hyperbolic universe, where the hyperbole is so heavily bent by its own gravity, that it closes in all three planes and becomes a torus.
Like, imagine you take a square sheet of cloth and connect two and two corners together, so it forms a tube and then connect the two ends of the tube into a ring, you'll notice, that you bent a flat sheet until all four corners touched and it became a torus. At this point you reached the maximum curvature.

The universal constant is a state of equilibrium, which all matter and energy eventually end up in. My guess is that the Universe is "flat" because that is a form of equilibrium. Or in other words, it is the most stable state at which the universe could exist. However, I'll venture to bet that the universe hasn't always been in that state. In fact, assuming the big bang was the cause of this form of the universe...

(I have my own theories that there was never a "beginning" to everything and that there won't be an "end" either, but only a cycle of changing forms of matter and energy, just as we see on a smaller scale on earth. Every atom that your body is made up of has existed on earth since it's creation, unless you've got a couple carbon atoms from the asteroid that killed the dinosaurs in you. And when you die, those atoms will change into yet another state, and continue on after your physical being. I'm happy to discuss and debate this idea as well)

...then I think it would be safe to assume that at one point, the universe had a much higher density due to its overall smaller size relative to the dimensions of our current observable universe. And if we are assuming that life, energy, and matter all work on a cyclical basis through the cosmos (and for the sake of argument, we are) then it's highly possible, if not probable, that withing the next several billion years, the universe will yet again collapse upon itself, causing the end to this current phase of existence in preparation for yet another one to occur.

What This video fails to mention is that space most likely only appears to be flat due to its size being too large to detect any curvature. A triangular shape was cast across space & the angles of a flat surface should measure 180°.  Greater than 180° would mean a closed shaped universe and less than 180° would mean open shaped.  The results came back to within 4/10 of a %.  The problem being if the entire universe is 250x larger than the observable universe,  then the results could be outside the margin of error to successfully determine the shape if the universe. .  250 x 4/10ths = 100%.  This is why Physicists like myself are torn on this Question.

It's worth considering that maybe life has a lot more trouble existing in universes which aren't nearly flat, and the near flatness of ours is a result of the fact that we are part of the vast majority of universes which have life which are flat. It's also worth considering that, if the flatness of a universe is statistical, the chances of our universe being exactly flat are the same as the chances of a random element of an infinite set being a particular element - exactly zero. This would imply that the universe definitely is (read: infinitely low chance that it isn't) a 3D analogue of either a hyperbolic, spherical, or elliptical plane, and that the curvature is so low that we currently can't accurately detect it since its effects are so small. Nice Idea, but you are missing the most important point: we can just measure the universe from what we can see/detect from the universe. This part is in astronomy/cosmology called the" local universe" and has a diameter of roughly 92 billion light years (yeah, thats more than two times 13,8 billion light years, due to the Guth Inflation). Nobody knows how big the universe (so everything) really is. We see just a part of it and don't know if that's just a tiny part of it or practically all. If we assume that the size of the universe is much larger than the size of our local universe, than this automatically means that our local universe must appear to be pretty flat to us, simply for geometrical reasons. An example: take a blown up ballon. Obviously this entity is strongly positively curved, right ? But if you just look at a tiny part of it's surface, than this part will appear to be pretty flat and not curved at all, although the balloon is obviously not flat at all. The bigger the balloon the flatter it will appear when just looking at a small part of it's surface. This means the measured curvature depends on the length over which curvature is measured and high the ratio of this length to the circumference is. Although I here use a 2D analogy, this is of course also generally valid for curved spacetime.
BTW: the error of margin when measuring the flatness of out local universe from the cosmic background radiation was around ~3%. This means if the overall universe would be just 33 times bigger, than out local universe is, it would appear that flat to us, not matter what the real curvature of the universe would truly be.

There is no "space", only an emptiness that serves to as a bridge between substance. Obviously particles/waves interact across this emptiness, but that doesn't mean the emptiness IS something. It is the nothing which particles require to express themselves fully, so each particle is expanding/contracting what we call space in order to express its wave-ness or particle-ness. You can't have Middle C expressed without 261.6 Hz of "space", but it is the note that has substance, not the space which it expands its form into. Similarly, (using the example from MinutePhysics) you wouldn't have 5 hydrogen atoms exist in a space for only 4.. or the reverse. When the energy or mass exists, it "creates" space for itself.

Assuming that an infinite number of parallel universes exist, and that the constants and laws of physics in those universes can vary wildly from our own, I think I can guess why our universe is so flat.

There could be an infinite number of universes where the laws of physics are identical to our own, but in which the matter density is different. I will assume that the density would have to be a very specific value for the universe to remain as flat as it is, and that a much larger portion of these otherwise identical universes would thus have a density value either higher or lower than ours, since that is much more probable. If the density has no effect on the probability of life emerging in these universes, we would expect to find ourselves in a universe with either positive or negative curvature, since those universes are much more numerous. Since we find ourselves in a (nearly) completely neutral universe, there are two different scenarios,

1: We were just incredibly lucky, nothing interesting to see here, move along

Or

2: The matter density (and thus the curvature of space) DOES have an effect on the probability of life emerging.

I believe the second scenario is the most likely. Life must simply find it much harder to appear in universes with a non-zero curvature, meaning that the only observers possible are those who observe a flat universe, which is precisely what we're currently doing.

Your explanation is misleading. It creates an impression that if you add matter to the universe (increase density) it will become positively curved while taking matter away will make it negatively curved (which is not the same as less curved, btw, contrary to what you say). In reality, the critical density is defined in terms of the Hubble parameter. If you add matter to a flat universe the energy density will increase, but so will the Hubble parameter (by Friedmann equation). So the ratio of density to the Hubble, which is the measure of flatness, would be unchanged. So in fact, no, if there had been fewer or more hydrogen atoms on average that wouldn't change the flatness of the universe. After all, the density was larger yesterday and it will be smaller tomorrow. Meanwhile, the universe is just as flat.

Excellent video. One point to clarify: in general relativity, the phenomenon of gravitation itself isn't really the result of space curving, but of time curving. One can show that the geodesic equation applied to a Minkowski metric containing only a small perturbation to the time-component leads to that perturbation being the Newtonian gravitational potential, i.e. the Schwarzschild metric. In other words, the overwhelming contribution to the gravitational field we experience in Newtonian-like systems (slowly moving, not too massive) is due to the time-like component of the metric deviating from flatness. The spatial curvature only shows up in minute details like gravitational waves or the geodetic effect, unless the curvature is large such as in a lensing cluster or near a black hole. I stress this point so because it is an easy topic of confusion when trying to understand relativity and why it explains so much. Most people forget the importance of space-time being four-dimensional in relativity, and the paradigm shift from space and time being static to being players in the game of physics. But a great presentation nonetheless :)
